ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Primarily the 4 cornerstones of language: reading, writing, speaking, and listening. Through in-class discussions, we also got a glimpse of Japanese culture and customs.
I developed my ability to speak, write, read, and understand Japanese. I also feel as though I developed my general ability to learn language and memorize words/phrases.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Honestly, I love basically everything about this course. Of course it forces you to learn things at a rapid pace, but it is very well-designed for learning.

Strengths: constant use of words in class allowed for a lot of practice, and while we went at a quick pace I never felt as though we were going too fast. 
Weaknesses: I feel as though for some words we didn't practice them as much in class which meant led to them not coming as naturally to me

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100% to every student who is willing to put in the work. Taking a language L1 is never easy (hence the 1.5 credits), and it can be very easy to begin falling behind, even from week 1 or 2. However, for those that are committed and/or are truly interested in learning the language, this class is an absolute must-take.
Yes. This class was very fun and (especially since this was L1) I felt as though I was constantly learning and getting much better.
